Award.AwardTitle: Conditional Inference Algorithms for Graphs, Tables, and Point Processes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The statistical challenges posed by discrete-valued matrix data (such as contingency tables, co-occurrence tables, adjacency matrices of graphs and networks, and multivariate binary time series) can often be greatly reduced by focusing on the conditional distribution of the pattern of entries in the matrix, given the margins of the matrix. Although this conditioning simplifies the statistical challenges, it greatly increases the computational challenges of any associated statistical procedures. This project has two principle aims: (1) to design practical methods and algorithms for statistical inference about the conditional distribution of a matrix given its margins, and (2) to specialize these methods and algorithms to the scientific needs of a variety of disciplines, including neuroscience, ecology, network analysis, educational testing, and combinatorial approximation.

With the advent of new technologies for gathering and storing large amounts of complex data, statistics is playing an increasingly central role in science, technology, engineering, medicine and commerce. These new data sources require new types of statistical thinking and improved statistical algorithms. This project develops new algorithms for the statistical analysis of networks, such as social networks, ecological networks, and brain networks. Preliminary results are already being used by neuroscience collaborators to better understand the structure of human seizures. This project also funds the training of graduate students who will become the next generation of innovators in science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was about new methods, computer algorithms, and mathematical theory relating to a special type of data that arises in many contexts, especially brain science.

Many scientific investigations generate discrete-valued matrix data. Co-occurrence tables in ecology are binary matrices indicating which species occur in which habitats. Point processes from multi-electrode recordings in neuroscience are binary matrices indicating which neuron had an electrical spike in which time bin. The connectivity structure of graphs and networks, such as social networks, biological networks, and artificial networks, can be represented by an adjacency matrix indicating which nodes are connected together. Two-way contingency tables of all kinds are integer-valued matrices. These types of data create many statistical challenges, not only because the data is high-dimensional and often sparse, but because the relationships and dependencies in the data are complex and can span multiple spatial and temporal scales. This project was focused on developing statistical theory and methodology for analyzing this type of data.

The project was largely successful, with new algorithms developed for analyzing brain data, including data from human patients experiencing seizures, for analyzing more generic binary-matrix-valued data, for clustering data into interesting groups, and for brain-computer interfaces, including applications for neural prosthetics for paralyzed people. The project also led to the development of some surprising new theory regarding the limits of statistical inference in extremely data-sparse settings.

This project supported the training of a PhD student who successfully defended his PhD dissertation at the conclusion of the grant. Training the next generation of data scientists is a crucial part of maintaining the vibrancy of our country's technological workforce.
